title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
notes:
Continuous micro-stuttering. Most noticeable when looking up/down, it appears that the frames are rendered out of order, e.g. 1,3,2,4,6,5,7 etc...
When encountering a shader for the first time, the initial quick compile will often generate a very white shader, and a few seconds later it is fine.
The shader (probably compile) issue reduces significantly after playing a few minutes, and doesn't repeat when re-starting the game.
Framerate is however excellent.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
notes: Stable gameplay. Keyboard problems (Caps lock toggle run/walk problem, moving direction problems), can't save, can't change options, and can't access addons option.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
notes: Only played the beginning, and that was completely stable.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
notes:
The missing/crackling audio can easily be fixed by the linked guide. Not as tedious as it may seem! On a sidenote: in my case, setting xaudio2_6 to native and xaudio2_7 to builtin did the trick, and the Windows version is set to 8.1. No issues whatsoever, excellent performance.
https://www.reddit.com/r/linux_gaming/comments/99i4se/skyrim_on_linux_steam_play_no_voiceno_music_audio/

gpu: Intel Open Source Technology Center Mesa DRI Intel(R) Ivybridge Mobile x86/MMX/SSE2
notes: When creating the wine prefix, proton uses the system default language, french in my case, but i always use steam in english, so the game didn't find its 'My documents' folder because it was translated in french. I just had to rename it to make the savegames working. Having proton creating the wine prefix with steam language instead of system, or always adding english versions of such userdirs would cure it definitly, i think
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: I play in english while my system is in french. I only had to rename "Mes documents" as "My documents" in the wine prefix to have the savegames working. The game works out of the box otherwise

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes:
Started a new save and played about an hour until I reached Whiterun. I used the Unofficial Skyrim Legendary Edition Patch from the workshop. Particle effects (fire, basically) seems to make the game struggle FPS wise (not a steady 60) and cause quite a bit of input lag for some reason. Since the beginning of the game has an unusually large amount of fire, performance didn't look great.  However, during my hour of play I didnt' encounter other areas with these issues.

Pressing caps lock to toggle between run and walk doesn't always register, or register unreliably. The game hangs on exit which is a fairly old bug and apparently also occurs on Windows, though rarely.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Framerates over 60 mess with the engine, used an FPS limiter mod to fix physics bugs. This was also slightly buggy though, so I set my monitor refresh rate to 60hz and that fixed a few things. Other than that, the mouse is slightly wonky and difficult to control
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Runs perfectly, except for bugs that also affect Windows. Had to alter PULSE_LATENCY_MSEC, but this is likely due to my setup specifically.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes:
Game can sometimes crash without reason.
Performance is lower than on windows.
Closing the game keeps the game process running in the background
Sometimes the game won't start at all and gives a black screen. Restarting Steam seems to allow the game to boot again.
Mods aren't working at all, Steam Workshop or manually installed. Though DLC does work.
Sometimes distorted audio plays when voices or background noises should be played. Reboot the game to fix it.

Even though it has all these issues, the game seems playable from beginning to end.

notes:
Framerate can be choppy in windowed mode, something truly hideous and confusing is going on with all shadows, dialogue and music do not load so only sound effects can be heard, and only mesh replacement mods seem to work; those that change mechanics or the layout of the world do not load.

All in all, playable, but a bit of a sub-par experience given the problems.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Audio usually starts to crackle after playing for 30 minutes to an hour, fixed temporarily by restarting Skyrim. Always hangs when you try to quit and steals mouse focus, making force quit GUI hard to use (recommend binding a keyboard shortcut to "killall TESV.exe" before playing). Of course it still has all the same bugs as on Windows where you can't see underwater without a mod, menus don't always respond to mouse movement, Steam Workshop support is broken, doesn't support ultrawide resolutions, etc.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Runs fine with no tweaks. A hang when quitting to desktop was the only issue in 40mins of playtime.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes:
Game can sometimes crash without reason.
Performance is lower than on windows.
Closing the game keeps the game process running in the background. 
Sometimes the game won't start at all and gives a black screen.
Restarting Steam seems to allow the game to boot again.
Mods aren't working at all, Steam Workshop or manually installed. 
DLC does work.
Sometimes distorted audio plays when voices or background noises should be played. Reboot the game to fix it.

Even though it has all these issues, the game seems playable from beginning to end.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Runs pretty great overall @ 1080p Ultra Settings (using FXAA) with all DLC / no mods installed. Didn't run entirely ootb and still has a few annoyances: Cloud Sync of Saves only worked partially; Launcher throws error messages, though inconsequential; Playing with Steam Controller in Keyboard Mode doesn't allow remapping in game (Recognizes all keys as "0x45"); Quitting the game always causes a freeze; No sound crackling issues for me, lip sync can be off at times though.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Doesn't start if you click Play after the error message on the launcher. Click it before and it's fine. Many glitches when going through doors. Horrendous physics glitches e.g. items flying around, you falling through bridges. This I believe is an FPS related problem as it happens on Windows. I got 144FPS, but I didn't make any changes to allow it. Game still hangs on exit. I needed to reboot my PC. I think 3.7-8 is more stable than 3.16-3. Playable but annoying.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Stable framerates (lower than windows) but otherwise perfect
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Running the "Legendary Edition" (all DLC, but not the "Special" edition).  Everything works out-of-the-box.  I use an XBox clone controller mostly but Keyboard works fine, too.  No issue with sound or graphics at all.  Because physical constraints limit me to a GT 1030, at 1080p I default to "HIgh" settings but dial-down anti-aliasing to 4x (I honestly can't see the difference) for a decent frame-rate boost to approx 60 fps average.  It has the same foible as under Windows in that it's best to quit to the main menu, alt-tab to a terminal and issue "pkill TESV" unless you disable (deselect) Dawnguard DLC which then allows you to quit normally to desktop.  Personally I'd prefer to retain the DLC and live with this as a minor irritation.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

notes: Everything seems to work, even have an ENB and oodles of mods, but struck with the "64hz bug" with, as on Windows, no fix.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
